moves.1. e4: Once more as White I choose to open with the King's Pawn.  This will be the last of these for awhile, since I have recently switched to the English Open in my games at the coffee shop due to there being less lines for me to memorise.  However, I still believe King's Pawn to be the most beneficial opening move for White, allowing you to avoid many types of slow manoeuvring games.
moves.1... c5: Black responds with the Sicilian, my favourite response to White's e4 opening.
moves.2. Nf3 Nc6: Both natural development moves, allowing each player to stake a claim on the centre of the board.
moves.3. Bb5: White moves into the Rossolimo Variation of the Sicilian.  The aim of this is to allow for early castling while still building a strong central pawn structure, something White is often denied in the Sicilian.  When masters play, Bb5 is considered a move aimed at drawing the match but when Black is not prepared or unaware of the theory it can allow for White to gain a considerable advantage.
moves.3... Qc7: Considered to be "in book", I personally don't like it.  I think either e6 or d6 is the preferred move for Black here, attempting to gain an advantage in the centre.
moves.4. O-O e5: Early castle followed by Black leaving the "book" moves for the  Rossolimo (which called for a6 here). e5 is well defended and gives Black a double threat on the unoccupied d4 square - I've always been told that control of the centre is essential for winning a chess match so Black is looking good.
moves.5... Nf6: Black threatens the undefended e4 pawn.
moves.6. d4 cxd4 7. cxd4 exd4: Black wins the exchange in material, creating doubled up passed pawns on the d-file in the process.  White's e4 pawn is still under threat and Black is already up in material.
moves.8. e5: White moves his e pawn to relative safety, threatening the Black Knight.
moves.8... Nd5: The Black Knight runs to immediate safety, but. . .
moves.9. Qb3: White continues the chase and threatens him again.
moves.9... Nce7: Black moves his Knight to defend the threatened Knight.  I preferred a6 here, threatening the exchange of Knight for Bishop.
Now White moves to take advantage, first by attacking the Black Queen.
moves.16... Qd7: And again, Black rushes to move to safety and commits a second mistake, the Hang mentioned in the title.  By moving here, Black hangs his pawn at e5, which White can take and check the Black King.  The furthest I went into the line was to move 23 (17.Qxe5+ Ne6 18.Bb4 Qc7 19.Qf5 Qf4 20.Qxf4 Nxf4 21.Nxf7 Be6 22.Bxe6 Nxe6 23.Nxh8 a5), which puts Black down by a Rook and two Pawns.  I think the move that should've been made is b6, which does sacrifice the Rook but keeps the King safe.
moves.17. Qxe5+: Pins Black's pawn at g7, forks Black's King and Pawn at g7 and isolates Black's pawn at d4.  White can almost taste victory.
moves.17... Ne6 18. Bb4: White prevents the Black King from castling and keeps the pressure on Black.
moves.18... h6: And the final part of the title, Black moves into mate.  At the time I was unaware it was forced mate from here, but it certainly felt good.  During analysis, I discovered from here we're looking at 19.Rfe1 a5 20.Nxe6 fxe6 21.Bxe6 Qxe6 22.Qxg7 axb4 23.Rac1 Qxe1+ 24.Rxe1+ Be6 25.Rxe6+ Kd8 26.Qxd4+ Kc8 27.Re7 Kb8 28.Qe5+ Ka7 29.Qc5+ Kb8 30.Qc7+ Ka7 31.Qxb7#.  If I'm incorrect, please correct me but I'm fairly sure I'm right.  I think the best move was Qc7, with an eye for playing 18...Qc7 19.Qf5 Qf4 20.Qxf4 Nxf4 21.Nxf7 b5 22.Rfe1+ Kd7 23.Re7+
moves.19. Rfe1 hxg5 20. Qxg7 Kd8 21. Ba5+: I still hadn't spotted a mate, so kept pressure on the Black King instead.
moves.21... Ke8: But after Black moved Ke8 I finally spotted a lovely little sequence that  led to mate.

gameName: Game Number 9 - A Pin, a Hang and Moved into Mate
